{{convert|102|mph|abbr=on}}[http://www.estevanmercury.ca/article/GB/20130210/CP02/302109965/-1/estmercury01/blizzard-that-buried-maritimes-and-central-canada-blasts-into&template=cpart Blizzard that buried Maritimes and central Canada blasts into Newfoundland | National News | Estevan Mercury, Estevan, SK] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140109011558/http://www.estevanmercury.ca/article/GB/20130210/CP02/302109965/-1/estmercury01/blizzard-that-buried-maritimes-and-central-canada-blasts-into%26template%3Dcpart |date=January 9, 2014 }} |total damages (USD) = Unknown |areas affected = {{Flatlist| * [[Eastern United States]] * [[Canada]] ([[Atlantic Canada]], Central Canada) * [[Iceland]] * [[British Isles]]}} |total fatalities = 18 fatalities | notes = '''Part of the [[2012–13 North American winter]]''' }} The '''Early February 2013 North American blizzard''' was a powerful [[blizzard]] that developed from the combination of two [[Low-pressure area|areas of low pressure]],{{cite web|title=Massive snowstorm seen from space in satellite photo|author=Clara Moskowitz|publisher=CBS News|date=February 8, 2013|accessdate=February 9, 2013|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-205_162-57568443/massive-snowstorm-seen-from-space-in-satellite-photo/}} primarily affecting the Northeastern United States and parts of Canada, causing heavy snowfall and [[Beaufort scale|hurricane-force winds]]. The storm crossed the Atlantic Ocean, affecting Ireland and the United Kingdom.{{cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/uk/377104/Warning-as-snowstorm-Nemo-heads-for-Britain|title=Warning as snowstorm Nemo heads for Britain|first=Nathan|last=Rao|date=12 February 2013|publisher=}} The nor'easter's effects in the United States received a Category 3 rank on the [[Northeast Snowfall Impact Scale]], classifying it as a "Major" Winter Storm. The first low-pressure system, originating from the [[Northern Plains]] of the United States, produced moderate amounts of snow across the [[Great Lakes region]] of the U.S. and Canada.{{cite web|title=Snow Summary - February 7-8, 2013|author=|date=February 9, 2013|accessdate=February 9, 2013|publisher=National Weather Service|url=http://www.crh.noaa.gov/images/grr/presentations/Storm_Summary_February_7th_and_8th_2013_2013-02-08_17-26-08.pdf}} The second low, originating across the state of [[Texas]], produced heavy rains and flooding across much of the [[Southeast United States|Southeast]] and [[Mid-Atlantic states|Mid-Atlantic]] parts of the U.S. As the two systems merged off the Northeast coast on February 8, 2013, they produced heavy snowfall over a large region from [[North Jersey]] and inland from New York City through eastern New England up to coastal [[Maine]] and inland to [[Ontario]]. Total snowfall in [[Boston, Massachusetts]], reached {{convert|24.9|in|cm}}, the fifth-highest total ever recorded in the city. New York City officially recorded {{Convert|11.4|in|cm}} of snow at [[Central Park]], and [[Portland, Maine]], set a record of {{convert|31.9|in|cm}}. [[Hamden, Connecticut]] recorded the highest snowfall of the storm at {{convert|40|in|cm}}, the second highest total in [[Connecticut]] was recorded in [[Milford, Connecticut|Milford]] at 38 inches. Many surrounding cities picked up at least {{convert|1|ft|cm}}. In addition to the significant snowfall totals, hurricane-force wind gusts were recorded, reaching {{convert|102|mph|abbr=on}} in [[Nova Scotia]], {{convert|89|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at [[Mount Desert Light|Mount Desert Rock, Maine]], and {{convert|84|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} off the coast of [[Cuttyhunk, Massachusetts]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ndbc.noaa.gov/data/realtime2/MDRM1.cwind|title=Mount Desert Rock Continuous Winds Data|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ndbc.noaa.gov/data/realtime2/BUZM3.cwind|title=Buzzards Bay, MA Continuous Winds Data|publisher=}} Boston experienced a [[storm surge]] of {{convert|4.2|ft|m|abbr=on}}, its fourth-highest.{{cite web|author=Jeff Masters|publisher=Weather Underground|date=February 9, 2013|accessdate=February 9, 2013|title=Snow measured in feet, not inches: historic Nor'easter pounds England|url=http://www.wunderground.com/blog/JeffMasters/comment.html?entrynum=2346}} The storm affected [[Atlantic Canada]] after hitting the Northeastern United States. Watches and warnings were issued in preparation for the storm, and state governors declared states of emergency in all states in [[New England]] and in New York. Flights at many major airports across the region were canceled, and travel bans were put into place on February 8 in several states. Hundreds ended up stranded on Long Island late on February 8 as a result of the rapidly accumulating snowfall. A combination of strong winds and heavy, wet snow left 700,000 customers without electricity at the height of the storm.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/02/09/us-usa-weather-idUSBRE91611P20130209|title=Blizzard hammers U.S. Northeast, five dead, 700,000 lose power|first=Tim|last=McLaughlin|publisher=}} At least eighteen deaths were attributed to the storm.{{cite web|title=Three Northport Men Die While Removing Snow|url=http://northport.patch.com/articles/three-northport-men-die-while-removing-snow|publisher=Northport Patch|accessdate=February 11, 2013}}{{cite news|publisher=CTV news|date=February 9, 2013|accessdate=February 9, 2013|title=At least 4 dead as blizzard moves east from Ontario|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/3-dead-as-blizzard-wallops-southern-ontario-1.1148213}}{{cite web|title=Wind, snowfall intensifying; More than 6 inches so far in Poughkeepsie, Rhineback|author=Mike Benischeck|work=Poughkeepsie Journal|date=February 8, 2013|accessdate=February 9, 2013|url=http://www.poughkeepsiejournal.com/article/20130208/NEWS01/130208002/Poughkeepsie-area-to-see-3-to-5-inches-of-snow-today-7-to-11-tonight}}{{cite news|title=5 Storm-Related Fatalities Reported|date=February 9, 2013|accessdate=February 9, 2013|publisher=NBC Connecticut|url=http://www.nbcconnecticut.com/news/local/One-Killed-in-Prospect-Crash-190511141.html}}{{cite web|url=http://cnews.canoe.ca/CNEWS/Canada/2013/02/07/20560166.html|title=(no title)|website=Canoe}} {{TOC limit|3}} ==Meteorological history== [[File:WPC LPA Forecast Feb 7 2013 0000z.gif|250px|left|thumb|WPC forecast graphic anticipating the development of the merging low-pressure areas on February 7]] Atmospheric conditions leading up to the formation of the February 2013 [[nor'easter]] were rather anomalous and were conducive for [[cyclogenesis]]. Such conditions included the presence of a [[ridge (meteorology)|ridge]] over the North Atlantic and the strengthening of a [[trough (meteorology)|trough]] in California.{{cite report|title=Great Lakes to Northeast Major Winter Storm|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/event_reviews/2013/Great_Lakes_Northeast_Winter_Storm_Feb2013.pdf|publisher=Weather Prediction Center|accessdate=8 January 2014|author=Krekeler, Jason|location=College Park, Maryland|format=PDF|date=April 9, 2013}} The impactful nature of the eventual winter storm event was first predicted in [[National Centers for Environmental Prediction]] (NCEP) and [[Hydrometeorological Prediction Center]] (HPC) forecasts at 1200 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]] on February 6,{{#tag:ref|The [[Weather Prediction Center]] was formerly known as the Hydrometeorological Prediction Center until March 5, 2013|group=nb}} when the accumulation of at least {{convert|4|in|mm|abbr=on}} of snow in the ensuing hours was considered a moderate probability in parts of [[Wisconsin]] and [[Michigan]].{{cite web|title=WPC Winter Weather Archive for products issued 12Z February 6, 2013|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/archives/web_pages/winwx/display_maps.php?prodtype=issued&proddate=02/06/2013&prodtime=12&allsent=no&actualprods=92e_2,93e_3,9ee_4,9fe_5|publisher=Weather Prediction Center|accessdate=8 January 2014|author=Pereira, Frank|location=College Park, Maryland|date=February 6, 2013}} Fueled by energy originating from the [[Gulf of Alaska]] and carried by the [[jet stream|polar jet stream]], a [[low-pressure area]] formed as anticipated in [[Montana]] at 1200 UTC the next day. The cyclone tracked in a general east-northeastward direction throughout the day,{{cite web|title=Mesoscale Discussion 120|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/products/md/2013/md0120.html|work=SPC Mesoscale Discussion|publisher=Storm Prediction Center|accessdate=8 January 2014|author=Cohen, Ariel|location=Norman, Oklahoma|date=February 7, 2013}} reaching central [[Indiana]] by early on February 8.{{cite web|title=Mesoscale Discussion 122|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/products/md/2013/md0122.html|work=SPC Mesoscale Discussion|publisher=Storm Prediction Center|accessdate=8 January 2014|author=Kerr, Brynn|location=Norman, Oklahoma|date=February 7, 2013}} As the low-pressure system over the [[United States Midwest]] developed, energy associated with the [[subtropical jet]] over the Mexican plateau tracked into the [[Gulf of Mexico]], resulting in the formation of another low-pressure area just off the [[Texas]] coast on February 7. Tracking eastward, the system produced isolated severe weather across the [[United States Gulf Coast]].{{cite web|title=Mesoscale Discussion 118|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/products/md/2013/md0118.html|work=SPC Mesoscale Discussion|publisher=Storm Prediction Center|accessdate=8 January 2014|author=Broyles, Chris|author2=Edwards, Roger|location=Norman, Oklahoma|date=February 7, 2013}} Nearing noon that day, the cyclone moved into the [[Florida Panhandle]].{{cite web|title=Mesoscale Discussion 119|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/products/md/2013/md0119.html|work=SPC Mesoscale Discussion|publisher=Storm Prediction Center|accessdate=8 January 2014|author=Dial, Greg|author2=Hart, John|location=Norman, Oklahoma|date=February 7, 2013}} By February 8, the low-pressure system had moved into [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]].{{cite web|title=Mesoscale Discussion 121|url=http://www.spc.noaa.gov/products/md/2013/md0121.html|work=SPC Mesoscale Discussion|publisher=Storm Prediction Center|accessdate=8 January 2014|author=Kerr, Brynn|author2=Thompson, Richard|location=Norman, Oklahoma|date=February 7, 2013}} Both the system in the Gulf of Mexico and the system in the Midwestern United States were supported by the same [[shortwave trough]]. Due to [[block (meteorology)|blocking steering patterns]], both storms began to gravitate towards the [[East Coast of the United States|Eastern Seaboard]]. The HPC began issuing periodic storm summary bulletins on the two low-pressure areas at 0300 UTC on February 8. Their forecasts suggested that the system associated with the subtropical jet stream would rapidly intensify near the [[United States East Coast]], later absorbing the system associated with the polar jet stream.{{cite web|title=Storm Summary Number 01 For Great Lakes and Northeast Major Winter Storm|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/2013/storm3/stormsum_1.html|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=8 January 2014|author=Monarski, Allison|location=College Park, Maryland|date=February 8, 2013}} A few hours later, the southern disturbance began a phase of barometric deepening as it tracked northeastward off the [[Outer Banks]], while the northern system maintained an easterly course into northwestern [[Ohio]].{{cite web|title=Storm Summary Number 02 For Great Lakes and Northeast Major Winter Storm|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/2013/storm3/stormsum_2.html|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=8 January 2014|author=Kong, Kwan-Yin|location=College Park, Maryland|date=February 8, 2013}} Beginning at 0000 UTC on February 9, the two systems began an extensive merging process, with the strengthening cyclone originating from the subtropics absorbing energy from the cyclone originating from the polar jet stream. This resulted in the cyclone off the United States East Coast to continue intensifying while the initial system to the northwest gradually diffused over the [[Mid-Atlantic states]].{{cite web|title=Storm Summary Number 05 For Great Lakes and Northeast Major Winter Storm|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/2013/storm3/stormsum_5.html|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=8 January 2014|author=Monarski, Allison|location=College Park, Maryland|date=February 8, 2013}} Throughout the day the resulting system continued to track to the northeast, bringing along with it a large swath of snowfall that tracked across [[New England]] and into Canada.{{cite web|title=Storm Summary Number 06 For Great Lakes and Northeast Major Winter Storm|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/2013/storm3/stormsum_6.html|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=8 January 2014|author=Kong, Kwan-Yin|location=College Park, Maryland|date=February 9, 2013}} By 1200 UTC, the extratropical cyclone had strengthened enough to classify it as a [[bomb (meteorology)|bomb]].{{cite web|title=Storm Summary Number 07 For Great Lakes and Northeast Major Winter Storm|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/2013/storm3/stormsum_7.html|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=8 January 2014|author=Ryan, Sean|location=College Park, Maryland|date=February 9, 2013}} At 2100 UTC on February 9, the extratropical cyclone reached its peak intensity with a minimum [[barometric pressure]] of 968 [[bar (unit)|mbar]] ([[pascal (unit)|hPa]]; 28.59 [[inches of mercury|inHg]]) while located roughly {{convert|200|mi|km|abbr=on}} off the coast of [[Massachusetts]]. After reaching peak intensity the system began to steadily weaken and depart the coast of [[New England]], tracking near [[Nova Scotia]] early on February 10, upon which the HPC issued their final storm summary bulletin.{{cite web|title=Storm Summary Number 09 For Great Lakes and Northeast Major Winter Storm|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/2013/storm3/stormsum_9.html|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|accessdate=8 January 2014|author=Monarski, Allison|location=College Park, Maryland|date=February 10, 2013}} Despite the discontinuance of bulletins, the extratropical cyclone continued to persist and assumed an easterly course. By February 13, the storm system had tracked just south of Iceland,{{cite web|title=Europe Weather Map Feb 13 2013 0000z|url=http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Analyse_20130213.gif|publisher=Freie Universität Berlin|accessdate=8 January 2014|author=Institut für Meteorologie|location=Berlin, Germany|date=February 13, 2013}} bringing a cold and warm front into the [[British Isles]].{{cite web|title=Europe Weather Map Feb 14 2013 0000z|url=http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Analyse_20130214.gif|publisher=Freie Universität Berlin|accessdate=8 January 2014|author=Institut für Meteorologie|location=Berlin, Germany|date=February 14, 2013}} The system then began to curve northward through the [[Norwegian Sea]] over the next few days,{{cite web|title=Europe Weather Map Feb 16 2013 0000z|url=http://www.met.fu-berlin.de/de/wetter/maps/Analyse_20130214.gif|publisher=Freie Universität Berlin|accessdate=8 January 2014|author=Institut für Meteorologie|location=Berlin, Germany|date=February 16, 2013}} before it was absorbed by a larger system on February 18.{{cite web|title=Mean Sea Level Pressure Analysis for the Northern Hemisphere – 0000 UTC February 18|url=http://nomads.ncdc.noaa.gov/ncep-charts/hires/20130218/gdas.sfc.mslp.thk.nh.anl.00.20130218.gif|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=8 January 2014|date=February 18, 2013}} {{clear}} ==Preparations== [[File:York44.JPG|right|thumb|300px|Winter storm warning at [[York University]].]] ===Canada=== [[Environment Canada]] issued winter storm warnings for much of [[Ontario]], while [[Toronto]] issued an extreme weather alert ahead of the storm.{{cite web|url=http://www.cp24.com/news/city-issues-extreme-weather-alert-ahead-of-winter-storm-1.1146536|title=City issues extreme weather alert ahead of winter storm|first=Chris|last=Kitching|date=7 February 2013|publisher=}} Several universities and colleges closed throughout [[Southern Ontario]].{{cite web|url=http://www.therecord.com/news/local/article/883271--widespread-closures-as-snow-buries-region|title=Waterloo Region Breaking News - Waterloo Region's Online Newspaper - TheRecord.com|website=TheRecord.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cp24.com/weather/winter-storm-school-closures-for-feb-8-2013-1.1147423|title=Winter storm: School closures for Feb. 8, 2013|first=Web|last=Staff|date=7 February 2013|publisher=}} Many flights were canceled in the region{{cite web|url=http://www.accomponent.ca/en/news/ottawa-flights-cancelled-delayed-because-heavy-snow-us|title=Ottawa flights cancelled, delayed because of heavy snow in U.S. - CUPE - Air Canada Component|website=www.accomponent.ca}} and [[Greyhound Canada|Greyhound]] canceled bus service to New York.{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/canadarealtime/2013/02/08/toronto-struggles-to-cope-with-snow/|title=Toronto Struggles to Cope with … Snow|first=Carolyn|last=King|date=8 February 2013|publisher=}} In the [[Canadian Maritimes|Maritimes]], blizzard warnings were in effect for parts of [[New Brunswick]]{{cite web|url=http://www.weatheroffice.gc.ca/warnings/report_e.html?nb16|title=Alerts for: Moncton and Southeast New Brunswick - Environment Canada|first=Environment|last=Canada|website=www.weatheroffice.gc.ca}} and all of [[Nova Scotia]] and [[Prince Edward Island]], with more than {{convert|50|cm|in}} possible.[http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/nova-scotia/story/2013/02/09/ns-power-outage.html Blizzard bearing down on Atlantic Canada] CBC.ca[http://www.weatheroffice.gc.ca/warnings/report_e.html?pei2#pei2-289cwhx-018200 Weather Warnings - Queens County P.E.I.] weatheroffice.gc.ca ===United States=== [[File:February 2013 Nor'easter 7 Feb 1515z.png|thumb|The precursor to the nor'easter over the Southeastern United States on February 7]] By late on February 7, 2013, [[winter storm warning]]s and [[winter weather advisory|winter weather advisories]] were issued for the northeastern United States, from the [[Upper Midwest]] to [[New England]]. There was also a [[blizzard warning]] for the [[New York metropolitan area]], all of Connecticut, all of Rhode Island, and eastern Massachusetts, as well as southeast New Hampshire and coastal Maine. On February 8, blizzard warnings were expanded to include inland portions of southeast New Hampshire, and inland portions of Maine's coastal counties.{{cite web|title=National Weather Service Forecast Office – Portland-Gray, Maine|url=http://www.erh.noaa.gov/gyx/|publisher=National Weather Service |date=February 8, 2013| accessdate=February 8, 2013}} By February 8, [[storm warning]]s and [[hurricane force wind warning]]s were in effect for the New England and Mid Atlantic waters, in addition to [[coastal flood warning]]s.{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/business/bloomberg/article/Blizzard-Cancels-U-S-Flights-Threatens-Snow-in-4262565.php|title=Blizzard Cancels U.S. Flights, Threatens Snow in New York|last=Sullivan|first=Brian|author2=Jim Polson|date=February 8, 2013|work=San Francisco Chronicle|accessdate=February 10, 2013}} In Chicago, officials deployed 199 snow trucks, and the [[Illinois State Toll Highway Authority]] sent 182 plows for its road system. In the northeast United States, the storm threatened beaches and dunes in areas affected by [[Hurricane Sandy]] from the previous October.{{cite news|work=The Wall Street Journal|title=Blizzard Barrels Toward Area|accessdate=February 7, 2013|date=February 7, 2013|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323951904578290332427844030 }} Due to the storm's threat, airlines canceled more than 2,700 flights, mostly for February 8. In New York, officials readied snow removal crews,{{cite news|author=Scott Malone|publisher=Reuters|title=New England to bear brunt of powerful blizzard|accessdate=February 7, 2013|date=February 7, 2013|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/02/08/us-usa-weather-idUSBRE91611P20130208}} with more than 250,000 tons of salt prepared. Schools were closed in [[Hartford, Connecticut]] and [[Providence, Rhode Island]], among other cities.{{cite news|author=Bridget Murphy|work=The Christian Science Monitor|date=February 7, 2013|title=Blizzard Nemo update: 2 feet of snow possible|accessdate=February 7, 2013|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/Latest-News-Wires/2013/0207/Blizzard-Nemo-update-2-feet-of-snow-possible}} [[Governor of Connecticut|Connecticut Governor]] [[Dan Malloy|Dannel Malloy]] declared a state of emergency at 12:00 p.m. EST (1700 UTC) on February 8, and closed limited-access highways statewide at 4:00 p.m.{{cite web|title=Declaration of Civil Preparedness Emergency|url=http://www.governor.ct.gov/malloy/lib/malloy/2013.02.08_Gov_Malloy_Declaration_of_Emergency.pdf|accessdate=February 11, 2013}} [[Connecticut Light and Power]] and [[United Illuminating]] planned for 30 percent of customers to lose power in Connecticut, and hired out-of-state line crews to assist with power restoration.{{cite news|title=Malloy Declares State of Emergency As Storm Covers Connecticut|date=Feb 8, 2013|work=[[Hartford Courant]]|url=http://www.courant.com/news/weather/hc-weather-snow-connecticut-0208-20130205,0,4715023.story}} Governor Malloy on February 9 ordered all roads in the state closed except to essential vehicles.{{cite web|title=CT Road Closures|url=https://twitter.com/CTDEMHS/status/300186840168804352|publisher=CT DEMHS| date=February 9, 2013 | accessdate=February 9, 2013}} [[Governor of Rhode Island|Rhode Island Governor]] [[Lincoln Chafee]] declared a state of emergency on February 8, and issued a travel ban for interstates and other major highways effective 5 p.m. EST.{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/news/weather/2013/02/08/gov-declares-state-emergency-for-major-storm/9aH1zik3D1pOKSZEz3nw7O/story.html|title=RI gov declares state of emergency for major storm – News – Boston.com|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/news/weather/2013/02/08/issues-non-essential-travel-ban-highways/T5RlX232sLWG5is7dcv2YP/story.html |title=RI issues non-essential travel ban on highways |work=The Boston Globe |date=February 8, 2013 | accessdate=February 9, 2013}} [[Governor of Massachusetts|Massachusetts Governor]] [[Deval Patrick]] declared a state of emergency at 12:00 p.m. EST on February 8, and banned vehicles from all public roads after 4:00 p.m.; it was the first statewide driving ban in Massachusetts since the [[Northeastern United States blizzard of 1978|Blizzard of 1978]], which happened to strike the region exactly 35 years and 1 day earlier. The ban, issued via executive order, included a penalty of one year in jail and/or a five hundred dollar fine. The ban did not apply to emergency vehicles, hospital workers, or the media.{{cite web|url=http://www.masslive.com/politics/index.ssf/2013/02/nemo_prompts_gov_deval_patrick.html|title=Nemo prompts Gov. Deval Patrick to declare state of emergency for Massachusetts|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/02/08/northeast-blizzard-warnings_n_2644643.html|title=Northeast Blizzard Warnings Posted As Region Braces For Up To Several Feet Of Snow|publisher=}} The [[Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority]] (MBTA) suspended subway, commuter rail, bus, and boat service at 3:30 p.m on February 8,{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/metrodesk/2013/02/08/mbta-riders-juggle-schedules-take-last-minute-rides/7l55auPdNXP7wfPbPJoB1N/story.html|title=Before the MBTA shut down at 3:30 p.m., riders juggled schedules so they weren’t left in the cold|date=8 February 2013|publisher=}} and flights at [[Logan International Airport|Boston Logan International Airport]] were suspended at 4:00 p.m.{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/businessupdates/2013/02/08/planes-are-still-flying-and-out-logan-but-service-will-suspended-friday/3nrh8DzAPzSdVFhRNc8NLN/story.html|title=Airlines halt service at Logan|date=8 February 2013|publisher=}} [[Boston]] mayor [[Thomas Menino]] ordered schools to close and recommended that businesses shut down during the storm. The [[National Hockey League]] postponed a game between the [[Boston Bruins]] and the [[Tampa Bay Lightning]] that was scheduled to be played at Boston's [[TD Garden]] on February 9 due to the nor'easter; the game was originally set for a delayed start of 7 p.m.; before the game was first delayed to 7 p.m. it was set for 1 p.m.{{cite web |url=http://tracking.si.com/2013/02/09/nhl-cancels-bruins-lightning-game-snow/ |title=NHL postpones Bruins-Lightning game in Boston due to snow |work=Sports Illustrated |date=February 9, 2013 |accessdate=February 13, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130213162309/http://tracking.si.com/2013/02/09/nhl-cancels-bruins-lightning-game-snow/ |archivedate=February 13, 2013 |df= }} [[Governor of New York|New York Governor]] [[Andrew Cuomo]] declared a state of emergency on February 8.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/new-york-state-has-declared-a-state-of-emergency-2013-2|title=New York State Declares A State Of Emergency|publisher=}} [[Governor of Maine|Maine Governor]] [[Paul LePage]] declared a state of emergency as well.{{cite web|url=http://www.mpbn.net/News/MaineHeadlineNews/tabid/968/ctl/ViewItem/mid/3479/ItemId/26115/Default.aspx |title=Maine Gov Declares State of Emergency |publisher=Mpbn.net |date=February 8, 2013 | accessdate=February 9, 2013}} [[Governor of New Jersey|New Jersey Governor]] [[Chris Christie]] activated his state's Emergency Operations Center on the morning of February 8.{{cite web|url=http://www.nj.com/politics/index.ssf/2013/02/christie_this_morning_activate.html|title=Christie activates N.J. Emergency Operations Center ahead of storm|publisher=}} More than 800 [[United States National Guard|National Guard]] soldiers and airmen were activated in Connecticut, Massachusetts and New York to support actions needed on state roads.{{cite web|title=Mammoth snowstorm knocks out power to more than half a million customers|url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/02/08/16895255-mammoth-snowstorm-knocks-out-power-to-more-than-half-a-million-customers?lite|publisher=NBC News| date=February 8, 2013 | accessdate=February 9, 2013}} ===United Kingdom=== The [[Met Office]] issued an amber warning for snow and ice for the weakened storm for between 09:05 till 23:55 GMT on Wednesday 13 February. The already existing Cold weather health alert was extended in anticipation of the storm. Forecasters also warned of severe drifting of snow ahead of the gale force winds. ==Impact== [[File:Yorkuniversitytorontocanada.ogv|thumb|Storm on [[Keele Campus (York University)|Keele Campus]], [[York University]], in [[Toronto]].]] ===Canada=== The storm brought significant snow to [[Southern Ontario|Southern]] [[Ontario]] from February 7 to February 8. Snowdrifts caused major disruptions on roads and freeways.{{cite web|author=Staff Writer|publisher=Bullet News|date=February 6, 2013|accessdate=February 9, 2013|title=Alberta Clipper + Texas Low = 'significant' snow storm Thursday night into Friday|url=http://www.bulletnewsniagara.ca/2013/02/06/updated-weather-alert-alberta-clipper-texas-low-significant-snow-storm-thursday-night-into-friday/|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130407135258/http://www.bulletnewsniagara.ca/2013/02/06/updated-weather-alert-alberta-clipper-texas-low-significant-snow-storm-thursday-night-into-friday/|archivedate=April 7, 2013|df=}} Nearly a thousand flights were canceled at [[Pearson International Airport]], as well as a numerous flights at [[Ottawa Macdonald-Cartier International Airport]], [[Montréal–Pierre Elliott Trudeau International Airport|Montreal–Pierre Elliott Trudeau International Airport]], and [[Billy Bishop Toronto City Airport]] (Toronto island).{{cite news|last=Piffer|first=Russell|title=Toronto storm cleanup could cost up to $4 million|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2013/02/09/toronto_storm_cleanup_cost_could_cost_up_to_4_million.html|newspaper=The Star|date=Feb 9, 2013}} The storm brought snow and high winds to [[Toronto]], [[Ottawa]] and [[Montreal]], as well as extensive flooding to parts of [[Nova Scotia]] and [[New Brunswick]]. In Toronto, it was the largest snowfall in 5 years with accumulations of {{convert|10|in|cm}} at the airport and {{convert|14.4|in|cm}} in downtown (And up to {{convert|18|in|cm}} in the suburbs). Power was disrupted for thousands of customers in [[Atlantic Canada]], and dozens of flights were canceled at [[Halifax Stanfield International Airport]] on February 9. All [[Marine Atlantic]] ferries on February 9 were canceled. [[Nova Scotia]] was hit with wind gusts up to {{convert|164|km/h|sp=us}}, and more than 21,000 [[Nova Scotia Power]] customers were without electricity as of the afternoon of February 9.{{cite news|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/atlantic-canada-under-snow-water-following-intense-winter-storm-1.1149907|title= Atlantic Canada under snow, water following intense winter storm|date=February 9, 2013|publisher=CTV|accessdate=February 10, 2013}} ===United States=== [[File:February 08-09, 2013 Blizzard Storm Total Snow Accumulation.gif|thumb|Snowfall totals in New England from February 8–9]] ====Northeast==== Snow and rainfall began at 9 a.m. on February 8 across [[New England]]; by late that day, totals reached {{convert|8|in|mm|abbr=on}} near [[Milton, Vermont]].{{cite report|author=Allison Monarski|date=February 7, 2013|title=Storm Summary Number 04 for Great Lakes and Northeast Major Winter Storm|publisher=NWS Weather Prediction Center|accessdate=February 8, 2013|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/storm3/stormsum_4.html}} Later that evening, snow was falling at {{convert|2|to|3|in|cm|0}} per hour in coastal Massachusetts, and at an extreme rate of over 6 inches per hour in parts of Connecticut.{{cite web|author=Erin McClam|author2=Kari Huus|title=Mammoth snowstorm knocks out power to more than half a million customers|date=February 9, 2013|accessdate=February 9, 2013|publisher=NBC News|url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/02/08/16895255-this-is-it-mammoth-winter-storm-lashes-northeast}} Thunder and lightning along with small hail were reported within the heavy band of snow in Connecticut. In Massachusetts, two neighborhoods in [[Quincy, Massachusetts|Quincy]] and about a dozen homes in [[Salisbury, Massachusetts|Salisbury]] were evacuated due to coastal flooding. Voluntary evacuation orders were issued for oceanfront residents in [[Revere, Massachusetts|Revere]], [[Marshfield, Massachusetts|Marshfield]], and [[Scituate, Massachusetts|Scituate]].{{cite web|url=http://boston.cbslocal.com/2013/02/09/blizzard-flooding-forces-several-evacuations-in-salisbury-quincy/|title=Blizzard Flooding Forces Several Evacuations In Salisbury, Quincy|date=9 February 2013|publisher=}} Early on February 9, mandatory evacuations were ordered for Massachusetts coastal regions near the town of [[Hull, Massachusetts|Hull]] due to possible flooding and high winds.{{cite news|title=Northeast digs out after deadly blizzard|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/02/09/us/northeast-blizzard/index.html |publisher=CNN|date=February 10, 2013|accessdate=February 10, 2013}} Parts of coastal New England experienced hurricane-force winds from the storm, with a peak gust of {{convert|89|mph|abbr=on}} in Mount Desert Rock, Maine. A maximum gust of {{convert|87|mph|abbr=on}} was recorded on the [[Isle of Shoals]], a small group of islands off the New Hampshire coast.[http://www.wunderground.com/weatherstation/WXDailyHistory.asp?ID=KNHPORTS4&day=9&year=2013&month=2 Weather Station History | Weather Underground] Winds of {{convert|84|mph|abbr=on}} were recorded in [[Buzzards Bay]] near [[Cuttyhunk, Massachusetts]], and Boston's [[Logan International Airport|Logan Airport]] measured a wind gust of {{convert|76|mph|abbr=on}}.{{cite web|author=Andrew Freedman|publisher=Climate Central|date=February 9, 2013|accessdate=February 9, 2013|title=Blizzard Buries New England, Breaks Snowfall Records|url=http://www.climatecentral.org/news/blizzard-buries-new-england-breaks-snowfall-records-15582}} When the snow stopped, the highest amount recorded was {{convert|40|in|cm}} in [[Hamden, Connecticut]]. The {{convert|31.9|in|cm}} of snow in [[Portland, Maine]], set a new record for the city from a single snowstorm, and [[Gorham, Maine]] set a record for the state of {{convert|35.5|in|cm}}. It was the second highest total in [[Hartford, Connecticut]], with {{convert|22.8|in|cm}}; [[Concord, New Hampshire]], received {{convert|24|in|cm}} of snow. [[Boston]] received {{convert|24.9|in|cm}} of snow, the fifth highest total in the city from a single storm. It was the third-largest snowfall in [[Worcester, Massachusetts]], at {{convert|28.7|in|cm}}.{{cite news|title=Slow recovery for Northeast after epic blizzard|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/weather/2013/02/09/northeast-new-england-blizzard-nemo/1904347/ |work=USA Today|date=February 9, 2013}} At [[Central Park]] in New York, {{convert|11.4|in|cm}} of snow was recorded, while other parts of the city accumulated as much as 16 inches. Much of Long Island was hit with over {{convert|2|ft|cm}} of snow, with snowfall as high as {{convert|33.5|in|cm}} being recorded in [[Medford, New York|Medford]], in [[Suffolk County, New York|Suffolk County]].{{cite news|title=Long Island Snow Totals (UPDATED)|url=http://www.longislandpress.com/2013/02/09/long-island-snow-totals/|newspaper=[[Long Island Press]]|date=February 9, 2013}} ====Other affected areas==== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | header = Snowfall accumulation in {{nowrap|New England}} | width = 200 | image1 = Winter Blizzard 2013, Billerica MA.jpg | alt1 = | caption1 = The snowfall in [[Billerica, Massachusetts]] | image2 = Providence from Prospect Park after Blizzard Nemo.jpg | alt2 = | caption2 = Snow cover in [[Providence, Rhode Island]] | image3 = Shoveled sidewalk after February 2013 nor'easter, Walden, NY.jpg | alt3 = A sidewalk at the bottom of a crudely cut trench through the snow. Some snow on it is melting in the sun. | caption3 = A sidewalk shoveled after the storm in {{nowrap|[[Walden, New York]]}} }} The secondary low over [[Indiana]] produced light to moderate snowfall that extended to [[Wisconsin]]. Totals reached {{convert|11.6|in|cm|abbr=on}} in [[Muskegon, Michigan]]. The storm previously dropped {{convert|1.5|in|cm|abbr=on}} of snow in Chicago,{{cite web|url=http://www.weather.com/news/weather-winter/winter-storm-nemo-reports-20130208|title=Winter Storm Nemo: Snow, Wind, Coastal Flood Reports|last=Dolce|first=Chris|date=February 9, 2013|publisher=The Weather Channel|accessdate=February 10, 2013}} and {{convert|8.5|in|cm|abbr=on}} was reported in [[Beach Park, Illinois]] on February 8.{{cite web|url=http://palatine.patch.com/articles/update-winter-storm-nemo-leaves-up-to-95-inches-of-snow-across-northern-illinois|title=UPDATE: Winter Storm Nemo Leaves up to 9.5 Inches of Snow Across Northern Illinois|last=Grom|first=Korrina|date=February 8, 2013|publisher=Palatine Patch|accessdate=February 10, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130411150407/http://palatine.patch.com/articles/update-winter-storm-nemo-leaves-up-to-95-inches-of-snow-across-northern-illinois|archivedate=April 11, 2013|df=}} Several traffic accidents were reported in Illinois.{{cite news|agency=Chicago Tribune|date=February 7, 2013|title=Winter storm: Snow tapers off here, Northeast braces for blizzard|accessdate=February 7, 2013|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/chi-weather-story-20130207,0,7259661.story}} ====Power==== The [[Nuclear Regulatory Commission]] said the [[Pilgrim Nuclear Power Plant]] in [[Plymouth, Massachusetts]] experienced an automatic shutdown at around 9:15 p.m. EST on February 8 after losing off-site power; there was no threat to the public.{{cite web|title=Mass. nuclear power plant loses power, shuts down during snowstorm; NRC monitoring|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/mass-nuclear-power-plant-loses-power-shuts-down-during-snowstorm-nrc-monitoring/2013/02/09/835bacf4-727e-11e2-b3f3-b263d708ca37_story.html|work=The Washington Post| date=February 9, 2013 | accessdate=February 9, 2013}} The storm caused power outages, shortages at gas stations, and numerous car accidents across the region.{{cite web|url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/02/08/16895255-very-serious-winter-storm-begins-battering-new-england |title='This is it': Mammoth winter storm lashes Northeast |publisher=Usnews.nbcnews.com |date=February 8, 2013 | accessdate=February 9, 2013}} As of 12:45 a.m. EST on February 9, 321,000 customers were without power in [[Massachusetts]], 191,000 in [[Rhode Island]], and 32,000 in [[Connecticut]]. By 10:30 a.m., more than 655,000 customers were without power due to the storm, including 405,000 in Massachusetts and 185,000 in Rhode Island.{{cite web|url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/02/09/16908958-monster-storm-dumps-more-than-3-feet-of-snow-on-parts-of-northeast|title=Clobbered by record-setting blizzard, Northeast begins to dig out|first=U.S.|last=News|publisher=}} As of the evening of February 9, approximately 575,000 people were without power.{{cite web|title=Clobbered by record-setting blizzard, Northeast begins to dig out|url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/02/09/16908958-clobbered-by-record-setting-blizzard-northeast-begins-to-dig-out?lite|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=February 10, 2013}} As of the late evening of February 9, 344,000 customers were without power in Massachusetts and 31,000 in Connecticut. About 390,000 remained without power in total in the Northeast.{{cite web|title=Lights slowly coming back on in Northeast|url=http://www.cfnews13.com/content/news/cfnews13/news/article.html/content/news/articles/ap/2013/02/09/Lights_slowly_coming_back_on_in_Northeast.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130407215823/http://www.cfnews13.com/content/news/cfnews13/news/article.html/content/news/articles/ap/2013/02/09/Lights_slowly_coming_back_on_in_Northeast.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=April 7, 2013|publisher=CFN13|accessdate=February 10, 2013}} In total, utility companies reported about 700,000 customers were without power across nine states.{{cite news | date = February 10, 2013 | title = Anxiety Grows as Thousands Remain Stranded and in the Dark After Storm | author = Nate Schweber |author2=Jess Bidgood | work = [[The New York Times]] | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/11/us/after-the-big-snowfall-the-struggle-to-dig-out.html?pagewanted=all }}{{cite web|title=Blizzard hammers Northeast, nine dead, 700,000 lose power|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/02/10/us-usa-weather-idUSBRE91611P20130210|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=February 10, 2013}} As of Sunday{{clarify|date=February 2013}} evening, there were still about 205,000 customers in Massachusetts without power. Some areas were projected not to have power restored until Thursday February 14.{{cite news|title=Live blog: New England blizzard watch February 2013|url=http://live.boston.com/Event/Live_blog_New_England_snow_storm_February_2013|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|accessdate=February 11, 2013}} The Pilgrim Nuclear Power Plant lost power again on February 10, after an offsite outage had caused a shutdown on February 8. A spokeswoman for [[Entergy]] Corp., the Louisiana company that owns Pilgrim said, "There's no worker or public safety concern," she said. "We're troubleshooting the cause." {{citation needed span|text=On Long Island, upwards of 40,000 people lost power, with downed wires from tree limbs and heavy snows being cited as the primary reason.|date=February 2013}} ====Travel==== More than 6,300 commercial flights were canceled on February 8 and 9.{{cite news|last=Mutzabaugh|first=Ben|title=Blizzard: Airline cancellations soar past 6,600|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/todayinthesky/2013/02/06/airlines-waive-fees-as-blizzard-menaces-northeast/1897609/|newspaper=USA Today|date=February 10, 2013}} In the New York City area, [[John F. Kennedy Airport]], [[LaGuardia Airport]] and [[Newark Liberty International Airport|Newark Airport]] opened 7 a.m. EST on February 9. In Boston, [[Logan International Airport]] reopened at 11 p.m. EST on February 9. Also, in Hartford, [[Bradley International Airport]] reopened at 6 a.m. EST on February 10.{{cite web|last=Hall |first=William |url=http://www.wfsb.com/story/21094344/bradley-airport-plans-to-reopen-sunday-morning |title=Bradley airport reopens Sunday morning - WFSB 3 Connecticut |publisher=Wfsb.com |accessdate=2013-02-10}} As of Sunday{{clarify|date=February 2013}} night, Logan Airport had limited service. Hundreds of cars got stuck on the [[Long Island Expressway]] in [[Suffolk County, New York|Suffolk County]] beginning the afternoon of February 8.{{cite news|title=Part of Long Island Expressway to be closed Sunday|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/hundreds-cars-stuck-long-island-expressway|publisher=Associated Press| date=February 9, 2013 | accessdate=February 9, 2013}} On February 10, from 7 a.m. to 5 p.m. EST, about 26 miles of the Long Island Expressway were closed between exits 57 and 73 for snow removal.{{cite web|title=26-mile stretch of LIE to shut down for snow removal Sunday|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=news/local/long_island&id=8983984|publisher=WABC TV|accessdate=February 10, 2013}} The closure was extended till 9 p.m. EST{{cite web|title=UPDATED: LIE Closure Extended Until 9 p.m.|url=http://sayville.patch.com/articles/lie-closed-sunday-for-snow-removal|publisher=The Patch|accessdate=February 11, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130213222922/http://sayville.patch.com/articles/lie-closed-sunday-for-snow-removal|archivedate=February 13, 2013|df=}} however, it was closed indefinitely as of 10:50 p.m. EST.{{cite web|title=LIE closed from exits 57-73 |url=http://longisland.news12.com/news/lie-closed-from-exits-57-73-1.4608605|publisher=News12|accessdate=February 11, 2013}} The westbound side of the Long Island Expressway opened early Monday{{clarify|date=February 2013}} morning, while the eastbound lanes between exits 57 and 73 remained closed for snow removal.{{cite web|title=Westbound LIE reopens, eastbound stretch still closed|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=news/local/long_island&id=8983984|publisher=WABC TV|accessdate=February 11, 2013}} At around 7 a.m. on February 11, both lanes of the Long Island Expressway reopened.{{cite web|title=AAA: Long Island Expressway Should've Stayed Open|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2013/02/11/all-lanes-of-long-island-expressway-reopened/|publisher=CBS New York|date=February 11, 2013}} ====Additional effects==== In the afternoon of February 9, a portion of the roof of Smithtown Lanes bowling alley in [[Smithtown, New York]] collapsed. There were no injuries as the business was closed at the time.{{cite web|title=Smithtown bowling alley roof collapses due to snow|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=news/local/long_island&id=8987059|publisher=WABC TV|date=February 9, 2013 |accessdate=February 9, 2013}} A house in Long Island suffered major structural damage due to heavy snow accumulation on the roof.{{cite web|title=Snapshot From A Storm: Heavy Snow Caves In Home's Roof On Long Island|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2013/02/09/snapshot-from-a-storm-heavy-snow-caves-in-homes-roof-on-long-island/|publisher=CBS2 News|date=February 9, 2013 |accessdate=February 9, 2013}} The [[Boston Bruins]] postponed their afternoon home game on Saturday, February 9 at the [[TD Garden]] against the [[Tampa Bay Lightning]] to Thursday, April 25.{{cite web |url=http://bruins.nhl.com/club/news.htm?id=654870 |title=Bruins/Lightning Game Postponed |author= |date=February 9, 2013 |publisher=BostonBruins.com |accessdate=February 9, 2013}} The [[Mohegan Sun]] resort casino in Connecticut postponed a Saturday{{clarify|date=February 2013}} night [[Bon Jovi]] concert, but the band played for the snowbound guests.{{cite web|title=Bon Jovi performs free concert for snowed-in fans|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=news/local/northern_suburbs&id=8987117|publisher=WABC TV|accessdate=February 10, 2013}} The [[United States Postal Service]] (USPS) suspended mail delivery in Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Rhode Island, Vermont, and parts of New York during and after the storm.{{cite news|url=http://about.usps.com/news/service-alerts/welcome.htm|title=Mail Service Updates: Winter Storm Nemo|date=February 9, 2013|publisher=[[United States Postal Service]] (USPS) |accessdate=February 10, 2013}}{{cite web | url = http://about.usps.com/news/service-alerts/msu_reports/2013/msureport_020913.pdf | title = Mail Service Disruption Report - Domestic | date = February 9, 2013 }} Many school districts on [[Long Island]], especially in [[Suffolk County, New York|Suffolk County]] closed schools for February 11.{{cite news|title=Long Island closings and alerts|url=http://longisland.newsday.com/long_island_school_closings/?pg=2&statusUpdatesQ=&az=&sort=alphabetically|work=Newsday|accessdate=February 10, 2013}} [[Boston Public Schools]] and several other school districts, including [[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]] and [[Somerville, Massachusetts|Somerville]], remained closed on February 11 and 12.{{cite web|title=Boston Public Schools Closed Monday|url=http://boston.cbslocal.com/2013/02/10/boston-public-schools-closed-monday/|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=February 10, 2013}} On February 10, President Obama declared a state of emergency for Connecticut.{{cite web|title=Obama approves emergency declaration for Connecticut|url=http://abclocal.go.com/wabc/story?section=news/local/northern_suburbs&id=8983486&rss=rss-wabc-article-8983486|publisher=WABC TV|accessdate=February 11, 2013}} ===United Kingdom=== {{unreferenced section|date=February 2013}} [[Southern England]] saw up to half a foot (15 cm) of snow, causing travel disruption right across the region. Flooding also was widespread further North and West, where milder air had caused a thaw, and heavy rain fell, which led to the Met Office issuing many Flood warnings. ==Fatalities== [[File:Nuns' Island 9 Feb 2013.jpg|left|thumb|[[Nuns' Island]] and a frozen [[Saint Lawrence River]] after the nor'easter]] ===Canada=== ====Ontario==== An 80-year-old woman in [[Hamilton, Ontario|Hamilton]], and an 80-year-old man in [[Niagara Falls, Ontario|Niagara Falls]] collapsed and died while shoveling snow.{{cite web|url=http://www.citynews.ca/2013/02/08/hamilton-woman-80-dies-while-shovelling-snow/|title=Hamilton woman, 80, dies while shovelling snow|publisher=City News Toronto|date=February 8, 2013|accessdate=February 10, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2013/02/10/two-die-in-ontario-while-shovelling-snow-after-fridays-massive-storm/|title=Two die in Ontario while shovelling snow after Friday's massive storm|date=February 10, 2013|accessdate=February 10, 2013|publisher=National Post}} A 49-year-old [[Oshawa]] man was killed in multi-vehicle collision in [[Pickering, Ontario|Pickering]]. A 57-year-old man from [[Ottawa]] died when his car crashed near [[Prescott, Ontario|Prescott]]. ===United States=== ====New England==== In Connecticut an 81-year-old woman using a snowblower was hit by a car in [[Prospect, Connecticut|Prospect]], a man in [[Bridgeport, Connecticut|Bridgeport]] was found dead under snow at his home, a man died after he suffered a heart attack while plowing snow in [[New Milford, Connecticut|New Milford]], a man from [[Shelton, Connecticut|Shelton]] died while digging his truck out of the snow, and police in [[Danbury, Connecticut|Danbury]] said a man was found dead on his back porch on February 9.{{cite web|title=After blizzard, Northeast region begins dig-out|url=http://www.ydr.com/nation-world/ci_22557226/after-blizzard-northeast-region-begins-dig-out|publisher=York Daily Record|accessdate=February 10, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130214023140/http://www.ydr.com/nation-world/ci_22557226/after-blizzard-northeast-region-begins-dig-out|archivedate=February 14, 2013|df=}} In Maine, a 75-year-old man crashed his vehicle into a tree in [[Passadumkeag, Maine|Passadumkeag]], then his pickup ended up in the [[Penobscot River]].{{cite news|title=Fatal Storm: Deaths Related To The Northeast Snow|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/fatal-storm-deaths-related-northeast-snow|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=February 10, 2013}} In [[Boston]], Massachusetts, a 13-year-old boy and a man died separately due to [[carbon monoxide poisoning]] while inside cars because the tailpipes were blocked by snow.{{cite news | title = Two die in carbon monoxide poisoning incidents in Boston; police urge caution when digging cars out of snow | work= [[The Boston Globe]] | date = February 9, 2013 | url = http://www.boston.com/metrodesk/2013/02/09/boston-boy-dies-carbon-monoxide-poisoning-after-shoveling-out-from-blizzard/jTgqG3MSPPRMy7CrIB7fbM/story.html }}{{cite web|title=Boy Dies From CO Poisoning In Snowed-In Roxbury Car|url=http://boston.cbslocal.com/2013/02/09/boy-goes-into-cardiac-arrest-after-co-poisoning-in-snowed-in-roxbury-car/|publisher=WBZ-TV Boston| date=February 9, 2013 | accessdate=February 9, 2013}} A man was killed in an automobile accident in [[Auburn, New Hampshire]] when his car spun out on a hill and collided with a tree, flattening the front end of his [[SUV]] and crushing him. ====Mid-Atlantic==== In New York, a man was plowing his driveway with a tractor on February 8 in [[Germantown (town), New York|Germantown]], when the tractor went off the edge of the road and fell on top of him. In [[Poughkeepsie, New York|Poughkeepsie]], a pedestrian was struck by a car and killed.{{cite news|title=1 dead, 500,000 without power from ongoing {{Infobox winter storm | name = Early January 2014 nor'easter | image = File:GOES-13 2 Jan 2014 1745z satellite.png | alt = | caption = The winter storm approaching the [[East Coast of the United States|East Coast]] late on January 2. | type = [[Extratropical cyclone]]
[[Nor'easter]]
[[Winter storm]] | formed = {{start date|2013|12|30}} | dissipated = {{start date|2014|01|06}} | RSI = 3.22 | lowest pressure = 936 | lowest temperature = -2°Fhttps://nypost.com/2014/01/03/winter-storm-hercules-kills-at-least-9/(Post-storm) | tornadoes = | fujitascale = | tornado duration = | highest winds = | gusts = | maximum snow = {{convert|23.8|in|m|abbr=on}} in Boxfield, [[Massachusetts]] | power outages = | total fatalities = 16 fatalities | damages = $50 million – $100 million | affected = [[Central United States]], [[Eastern United States]], [[Atlantic Canada]], [[Western Europe]] | current advisories = | enhanced = yes | notes = Part of the '''[[2013–14 North American winter]]''' }} The '''Early January 2014 nor'easter''' was a major [[winter storm]] that affected much of the [[East Coast of the United States|East Coast]] with snow, and frigid temperatures following the storm. The storm had dumped up to {{convert|2|ft|m|abbr=on}} of snow in some areas, especially around [[Boston, Massachusetts]]. == Meteorological synopsis == Late on December 30, a weak [[clipper]] system moved southward from [[Canada]]. The system produced light snow in the [[Midwest]] around areas like [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]] with only light accumulations. Starting on New Year's Day, however, the clipper began to strengthen and take an eastward turn. It would produce more moderate to heavy snow around areas like [[Cincinnati, Ohio]], with accumulations of roughly 4-6 inches. The storm then continued to move eastwards towards the [[East Coast of the United States|East Coast]], where it would continue to intensify. Early on January 2, the system started to become more complex as a new [[low pressure]] area had formed in the [[Gulf of Mexico]] along a stationary front. Winter storm warnings began to be issued by roughly mid-day from eastern [[New England]] to as far west as [[Pennsylvania]] as the storm closed in on the Northeast. By 3:00 p.m, the northern low began to weaken as the southern one began to take over as it continued to pull moisture from the Gulf of Mexico. This was the start of the storm's transition to a [[nor'easter]]. Later that night, the low pressure began to strengthen off the [[Southeastern United States|Southeast]] coast and move out to sea as it dumped snow on its northwestern side over the [[Northeastern United States]] and [[New England]]. Snow continued to fall into the early hours of January 3 even as it pulled away from the coastline. After it had left the coast early that morning, it continued to strengthen and turn to the northeast, and late on January 4, it reached its peak intensity of {{convert|936|mbar|inHg}} while situated near [[Greenland]]. It was then absorbed into another [[extratropical cyclone]], which later developed into [[Cyclone Christina]] which brought high winds to western Europe several days later. == Aftermath and cold wave == [[File:Christina 4 January 2014.jpg|thumb|[[Cyclone Christina]] (seen east of Newfoundland on January 4) later developed from the remnants of the nor'easter, bringing high winds and flooding to Western Europe.]] {{main|Early 2014 North American cold wave}} After the storm passed, an arctic front associated with it passed through the region, bringing record cold temperatures in the eastern half of the [[United States]]. On January 3, [[Boston]] had a temperature of {{convert|2|°F|°C}} with a {{convert|-20|°F|°C}} [[wind chill]], and over {{convert|7|in}} of snow. [[Boxford, Massachusetts]] recorded {{convert|23.8|in}}. [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]] had a record low of {{convert|-10|°F|°C}}. In [[Michigan]], over {{convert|11|in}} of snow fell outside Detroit and temperatures around the state were near or below {{convert|0|°F|°C}}. [[New Jersey]] had over {{convert|10|in}} of snow, and schools and government offices closed.{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/weather/2014/01/03/snow-cold-temps-disrupt-life-several-states/ZyFIVTLFhvz4miIVrTs2LO/story.html |title=Snow, cold disrupt large swath of US; more to come |work=Boston Globe |agency=Associated Press |date=January 3, 2014 |accessdate=January 10, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140114072632/http://www.boston.com/news/weather/2014/01/03/snow-cold-temps-disrupt-life-several-states/ZyFIVTLFhvz4miIVrTs2LO/story.html |archivedate=January 14, 2014 }} Over a dozen deaths were attributed to the cold wave, with dangerous roadway conditions and extreme cold cited as causes.{{cite news|last=DeMarche|first=Edmund|title='Polar vortex' set to bring dangerous, record-breaking cold to much of US|url=http://www.foxnews.com/weather/2014/01/04/polar-vortex-to-blast-frigid-air-over-much-us/|work=FoxNews.com|publisher=Fox News|accessdate=January 6, 2014|date=January 4, 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/11-died-winter-storm-dumped-feet-snow-northeast/story?id=21407724 |title=At Least 13 Died in Winter Storm That Dumped More Than 2 Feet of Snow Over Northeast |newspaper=ABC News |date=January 3, 2014 |last=Castellano |first=Anthony}}{{cite news |title=North America arctic blast creeps east |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-25632586 |work=BBC News |accessdate=January 7, 2014 |date=January 7, 2014}} Evan Gold of weather intelligence firm Planalytics called the storm and the low temperatures the worst weather event for the economy since [[Hurricane Sandy]] just over a year earlier.{{cite web|url=http://durangoherald.com/article/20140112/NEWS04/140119964/-1/s |title=Deep freeze may have cost economy about $5 billion, analysis shows |publisher=Durangoherald.com |date=January 10, 2014 |accessdate=2014-01-15}} 200 million people were affected, and Gold calculated the impact at $5 billion. $50 to $100 million was lost by airlines which cancelled a total of 20,000 flights after the storm began on January 2. [[JetBlue]] took a major hit because 80 percent of its flights go through New York City or Boston. Tony Madden of the [[Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis]] said with so many schools closed, parents had to stay home from work or work from home. Even the ones who could work from home, Madden said, might not have done as much. Not included in the total were the insurance industry and government costs for salting roads, overtime and repairs. {{citation needed |reason=Reliable source needed for the whole sentence |date=January 2014}}. == See also == *[[Mid-February 2015 North American blizzard]] – A similar storm that brought record cold temperatures behind it in its wake. *[[November 2014 North American cold wave]] *[[February 2017 North American blizzard]] - A similar storm that produced similar snow totals in the same areas. *[[:Category:Natural disasters in Massachusetts]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{United States winter storms}} [[Category:Nor'easters]] [[Category:December 2013 events]] [[Category:January 2014 events]] [[Category:2013 natural disasters in the United States]] [[Category:2014 natural disasters in the United States]]

'''Electrothermal-chemical''' ('''ETC''') technology is an attempt to increase accuracy and muzzle energy of future [[tank]], [[artillery]], and [[close-in weapon system]]<ref>{{cite book | first=Dr Norman|last=Friedman|author2=David K Brown |author3=Eric Grove |author4=Stuart Slade |author5=David Steigman | title=Navies in the Nuclear Age: Warships since 1945|publisher=Naval Institute Press|year=1993|pages=163|isbn=1-55750-613-2}}</ref> guns by improving the predictability and rate of expansion of [[propellant]]s inside the barrel.
An electrothermal-chemical gun uses a plasma cartridge to ignite and control the ammunition's propellant, using electrical energy to trigger the process. ETC increases the performance of conventional solid propellants, reduces the effect of temperature on propellant expansion and allows for more advanced, higher density propellants to be used.
The technology has been under development since the mid-1980s and at present is actively being researched in the United States by the [[Army Research Laboratory]], [[Sandia National Laboratories]] and defense industry contractors, including [[FMC Corporation]], [[General Dynamics Land Systems]], [[Olin Corporation|Olin Ordnance]], and [[Soreq Nuclear Research Center]].<ref>Taulbee, Steve (1993). [https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.c2979777;view=1up;seq=7 ARL Ballistics Research], U.S. Army Research Laboratory, p. 5.</ref> It is possible that electrothermal-chemical gun propulsion will be an integral part of US Army's future combat system and those of other countries such as [[Germany]] and the [[United Kingdom]]. Electrothermal-chemical technology is part of a broad research and development program that encompasses all electric gun technology, such as [[railgun]]s and [[coil gun]]s.
== Background == [[Image:XM360.png|right|thumb|305px|The XM360.]]
The constant battle between [[vehicle armour|armour]] and armor-piercing round has led to continuous development of the main battle tank design. The evolution of American anti-tank weapons can be traced back to requirements to combat [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] tanks. In the late 1980s, it was thought that the protection level of the Future Soviet Tank (FST) could exceed 700 mm of rolled homogeneous armour equivalence at its maximum thickness, which was effectively immune against the contemporary [[M829|M-829]] [[kinetic energy penetrator|armour piercing fin stabilized discarding sabot]].<ref>Ropelewski, ''Soviet Gains in Armor/Antiarmor Shape US Army Master Plan'', p.69</ref> In the 1980s the most immediate method available to NATO to counter Soviet advances in armour technology was the adoption of a 140 mm main gun, but this required a redesigned turret that could incorporate the larger breech and ammunition, and it also required some sort of automatic loader.<ref>Schemmer, ''Army, SecDef's Office at Loggerheads over Antiarmor'', p.53</ref> Although the 140 mm gun was considered a real interim solution it was decided after the fall of the Soviet Union that the increase in muzzle energy it provided was not worth the increase in weight. Resources were therefore spent on research into other programs that could provide the needed muzzle energy. One of the most successful alternative technologies remains electrothermal-chemical ignition.
Most proposed advances in gun technology are based on the assumption that the solid propellant as a stand-alone propulsion system is no longer capable of delivering the required muzzle energy. This requirement has been underscored by the appearance of the Russian [[T-90]] main battle tank. Even the elongation of current gun tubes, such as the new German 120 mm L/55,<ref>The length of the cannon can be found by multiplying the diameter of the barrel and the caliber length. For example, the M256, which is a 120 mm L/44, has a total length of 5.28 m, while the 120 mm L/55 has a total length of 6.6 m.</ref> which was introduced by Rheinmetall is considered only an interim solution as it does not offer the required increase in muzzle velocity.<ref>Sharoni, ''The Future Combat System'', p. 29</ref> Even advanced kinetic energy ammunition such as the United States' [[M-829A3]] is considered only an interim solution against future threats.<ref>Pengelley, ''The new era in tank main armament'', p.1522</ref> To that extent the solid propellant is considered to have reached the end of its usefulness, although it will remain the principal propulsion method for at least the next decade{{clarify|date=July 2015}} until newer technologies mature.<ref>Sharoni, ''The Future Combat System'', p.30</ref> To improve on the capabilities of a solid propellant weapon the electrothermal-chemical gun may see production as early as 2016.<ref>Kruse, ''Studies on Germany's Future 140 mm Tank Gun System'', p. 1</ref>
ETC technology offers a medium-risk upgrade and is developed to the point that further improvements are so minor that it can be considered mature.{{cn|date=July 2015}} The lightweight American 120 mm XM-291 came close to achieving 17 MJ of muzzle energy, which is the lower-end muzzle energy spectrum for a 140 mm gun.<ref>Diamond, ''Electro Thermal Chemical Gun Technology Study'', p.5</ref> However, the success of the XM-291 does not imply the success of ETC technology as there are key parts of the propulsion system that are not yet understood or fully developed, such as the plasma ignition process. Nevertheless, there is substantial existing evidence that ETC technology is viable and worth the money to continue development. Furthermore, it can be integrated into current gun systems.<ref>Sauerwein, ''Rheinmetall's NPzK''</ref>
== How it works == [[Image:ETC.png|right|thumb|305px|A diagram of a working electrothermal-chemical gun.]]
An electrothermal-chemical gun uses a plasma cartridge to ignite and control the ammunition's propellant, using electrical energy as a catalyst to begin the process. Originally researched by Dr. Jon Parmentola for the U.S. Army, it has grown into a very plausible successor to a standard solid propellant tank gun. Since the beginning of research the United States has funded the XM-291 gun project with USD 4,000,000, basic research with USD 300,000, and applied research with USD 600,000.{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}} Since then it has been proven to work, although efficiency to the level required has not yet been accomplished. ETC increases the performance of conventional solid propellants, reduces the effect of temperature on propellant expansion and allows for more advanced, higher density propellants to be used. It will also reduce pressure placed on the barrel in comparison to alternative technologies that offer the same muzzle energy given the fact that it helps spread the propellant's gas much more smoothly during ignition.<ref>Hilmes, ''Aspects of future MBT conception''</ref> Currently, there are two principal methods of plasma initiation: the flashboard large area emitter (FLARE) and the triple coaxial plasma igniter (TCPI).
=== Flashboard large area emitter === Flashboards run in several parallel strings to provide a large area of plasma or ultraviolet radiation and uses the breakdown and vaporization of gaps of diamonds to produce the required plasma. These parallel strings are mounted in tubes and oriented to have their gaps azimuthal to the tube's axis. It discharges by using high pressure air to move air out of the way.<ref>Diamond, ''Electro Thermal Chemical Gun Technology Study'', p.11-12</ref> FLARE initiators can ignite propellants through the release of plasma, or even through the use of ultraviolet heat radiation.<ref>Diamond, ''Electro Thermal Chemical Gun Technology Study'', p.13-15</ref> The absorption length of a solid propellant is sufficient to be ignited by radiation from a plasma source. However, FLARE has most likely not reached optimal design requirements and further understanding of FLARE and how it works is completely necessary to ensure the evolution of the technology. If FLARE provided the XM-291 gun project with the sufficient radiative heat to ignite the propellant to achieve a muzzle energy of 17 MJ one could only imagine the possibilities with a fully developed FLARE plasma igniter. Current areas of study include how plasma will affect the propellant through radiation, the deliverance of mechanical energy and heat directly and by driving gas flow. Despite these daunting tasks FLARE has been seen as the most plausible igniter for future application on ETC guns.<ref>For further technical information on FLARE ''see:'' P. Diamond</ref>
=== Triple coaxial plasma igniter === A coaxial igniter consists of a fully insulated conductor, covered by four strips of aluminum foil. All of this is further insulated in a tube about 1.6 cm in diameter that is perforated with small holes. The idea is to use an electrical flow through the conductor and then exploding the flow into vapor and then breaking it down into plasma. Consequently, the plasma escapes through the constant perforations throughout the insulating tube and initiates the surrounding propellant. A TCPI igniter is fitted in individual propellant cases for each piece of ammunition. However, TCPI is no longer considered a viable method of propellant ignition because it may damage the fins and does not deliver energy as efficiently as a FLARE igniter.<ref>TCPI is also covered in ''Electro Thermal Chemical Gun Technology Study'' by P. Diamond</ref>
== Feasibility == [[Image:60mmETC.PNG|right|thumb|305px|The 60 mm ETC gun developed by the US Navy at FMC as an ETC CIWS proof of principle demonstrator.]]
The XM-291 is the best existing example of a working electrothermal-chemical gun. It was an alternate technology to the heavier caliber 140 mm gun by using the dual-caliber approach. It uses a breech that is large enough to accept 140 mm ammunition and be mounted with both a 120 mm barrel and a 135 mm or 140 mm barrel. The XM-291 also mounts a larger gun tube and a larger ignition chamber than the existing M256 L/44 main gun.<ref>Pengelley, ''A new era in tank main armament'', p. 1522</ref> Through the application of electrothermal-chemical technology the XM-291 has been able to achieve muzzle energy outputs that equate that to a low-level 140 mm gun, while achieving muzzle velocities greater than those of the larger 140 mm gun.<ref>Sharoni, ''The Future Combat System'', p.31</ref> Although the XM-291 does not mean that ETC technology is viable it does offer an example that it is possible.
ETC is also a more viable option than other alternatives by definition. ETC requires much less energy input from outside sources, like a battery, than a [[railgun]] or a [[coilgun]] would. Tests have shown that energy output by the propellant is higher than energy input from outside sources on ETC guns.<ref>P. Diamond, ''Electro Thermal Chemical Gun Technology Study''</ref> In comparison, a railgun currently cannot achieve a higher muzzle velocity than the amount of energy input. Even at 50% efficiency a rail gun launching a projectile with a kinetic energy of 20 MJ would require an energy input into the rails of 40 MJ, and 50% efficiency has not yet been achieved.<ref>Horst, ''Recent Advances in Anti-Armor Technology'', p.6</ref> To put this into perspective, a rail gun launching at 9 MJ of energy would need roughly 32 MJ worth of energy from capacitors. Current advances in energy storage allow for energy densities as high as 2.5 MJ/dm³, which means that a battery delivering 32 MJ of energy would require a volume of 12.8 dm³ per shot; this is not a viable volume for use in a modern main battle tank, especially one designed to be lighter than existing models.<ref>Zahn, ''The Future Combat System: Minimizing Risk While Maximizing Capability'', p.20</ref> There has even been discussion about eliminating the necessity for an outside electrical source in ETC ignition by initiating the plasma cartridge through a small explosive force.<ref>Yangmeng, ''A Novel Concept of Electrothermal Chemical Gun without Power Supply'', p.1</ref>
Furthermore, ETC technology is not only applicable to solid propellants. To increase muzzle velocity even further electrothermal-chemical ignition can work with liquid propellants, although this would require further research into plasma ignition. ETC technology is also compatible with existing projects to reduce the amount of recoil delivered to the vehicle while firing. Understandably, recoil of a gun firing a projectile at 17 MJ or more will increase directly with the increase in muzzle energy in accordance to [[Newton's laws of motion|Newton's third law of motion]] and successful implementation of recoil reduction mechanisms will be vital to the installation of an ETC powered gun in an existing vehicle design. For example, [[OTO Melara]]'s new lightweight 120 mm L/45 gun has achieved a recoil force of 25 t by using a longer recoil mechanism (550 mm) and a pepperpot muzzle brake.<ref>Hilmes, ''Arming Future MBTs'', p.79</ref> Reduction in recoil can also be achieved through mass attenuation of the thermal sleeve. The ability of ETC technology to be applied to existing gun designs means that for future gun upgrades there's no longer the necessity to redesign the turret to include a larger breech or caliber gun barrel.
Several countries have already determined that ETC technology is viable for the future and have funded indigenous projects considerably. These include the United States, Germany<ref>Hilmes, ''Modern German Tank Development'', p.20-21.</ref> and the United Kingdom, amongst others. The United States' XM360, which is planned to equip the [[Future Combat Systems]] [[Mounted Combat System]] light tank and may be the [[M1 Abrams]]' next gun upgrade, is reportedly based on the XM291 and may include ETC technology, or portions of ETC technology. Tests of this gun have been performed using "precision ignition" technology, which may refer to ETC ignition.

'''Excon Worldwide, Inc.''' is a Canadian energy, commodities, equities, and services company based in [[Toronto]] with other offices worldwide. Its main location is in Toronto, [[Ontario]], [[Canada]]. The group comprises many specialized international offices and [[Subsidiary|subsidiaries]]. Excon Worldwide has more than seven thousand employees around North America and participates in markets around the world, including Canada, the United States, the UK, Australia, New Zealand, Asia, and the Middle East. Excon Worldwide has offices around the world including Toronto, [[Los Angeles]], [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]], [[New York City]], [[Houston, Texas]] and [[Hong Kong]].<ref>http://www.excon.com/</ref>
The Excon Worldwide, Inc. brand is used by the commodity trading divisions. The [[mortgage]], [[insurance]], and [[real estate development]] divisions are managed under a different brand. The only subsidiaries which kept the same name after being acquired by Excon Worldwide, Inc. were Cannix Energy Corporation and Excon Online.
Excon Worldwide is one of the largest commodity trading companies in North America. Excon Worldwide employs approximately 12,500 staff.{{when|date=January 2016}}
==History== Excon Worldwide was launched in 1987 as an energy trading and communications company. Since then, Excon has branched out into mortgages, insurance, and real estate development services. Excon opened its first American location in Los Angeles, the second location which followed was its Las Vegas executive office.
==Structure== Excon Worldwide owns several subsidiaries which have been renamed to fit under the Excon brand name. These subsidiaries include; [[Excon Mortgages]], [[Excon Insurance Group]], and [[Excon Development Group]]. The trading operations fit under the Excon brand name as well.
===Excon Mortgages=== The company, known previously as TTL Mortgage International, was founded on October 17, 1968.
In September 1990, Excon Worldwide announced that it would buy out TTL Mortgage International and relocate its headquarters to Los Angeles. These plans were suspended in January 1991, when the company announced its Los Angeles branch was moving to its new offices at 811 Wilshire Blvd, Los Angeles.<ref name="excon.com">http://www.excon.com/acquisitions.php</ref>
===Excon Insurance Group=== On December 21, 1999, Excon Worldwide bought all of the insurance operations of Ross & White Insurance Company. The company announced plans to complete the rebranding of Ross & White branches to Excon by late 2000. Since 2001 all Ross & White branches and offices have been rebranded Excon Insurance Group.
Chief executive Jacob White was flown in from Seattle to New York on the day the acquisition was completed, and eventually received a $5.5 million sign-on bonus and cash severance of $8.1 million after signing up as Excon Insurance Group's CEO.<ref name="excon.com"/>
===Excon Development Group=== In 2003, Excon Worldwide bought Las Vegas-based real estate development company [[Nevada Realty Developers Corporation]], bringing on current chairman Jonathan Dimon as President and COO and designating him as CEO Gregory Harrilson's successor. Dimon's pay pegged at 90% of Harrilson's. Dimon quickly made his influence felt by embarking on a cost-cutting strategy, and replaced former Excon Worldwide, Inc. executives in key positions with Nevada Realty Developers Corporation executives-many of whom were with Dimon since the beginning of his career at Nevada Realty Developers Corporation. Dimon became CEO in January 2006 and Chairman in December 2006. When Nevada Realty Developers Corporation was bought out by Excon Worldwide then CEO Gregory Harrilson was informed to change the name of the company to Excon Development Group, this allowed the real estate development giant to fit under Excon's branding web, and allowed the company to issue real estate development loans to other development companies for Excon Worldwide.<ref name="excon.com"/>
===Cannix Energy Corporation=== [[Cannix Energy Corporation]] is an energy and natural gas corporation based in [[Houston]], [[Texas]]. The company specializes in the energy industry by investing or developing energy power plants around the world. The company also specializes in the purchase and resale of energy treating it as a commodity. Founded in September 1971 Cannix Energy grew into one of the most profitable corporations based in Nebraska, the company employs over 500 people who specialize in the energy sector. In March 2005, Excon Worldwide acquired Cannix Energy for $602,070,000.
===Excon Online=== Excon Online is an internet company which specializes in [[internet advertising]], [[Computer programming|programming]], [[web development]], and is an [[internet service provider]]. The company was founded in late 2009 in Toronto, and was sold in 2011 to Excon Worldwide. Excon Online offers [[internet services]], [[web development]], [[Computer programming|programming]], [[internet advertising]], [[mobile advertising]], [[Search Engine Optimization]] (SEO).
==Offices== Although the old Excon headquarters were located in [[Mississauga]], Ontario, the current world headquarters for Excon are located at a new downtown office downtown Toronto.
The bulk of North American operations take place in two office locations, one in Toronto and the other in Calgary. The sales and trading operations take place in its Montreal head office. The operations involved in energy take place in Calgary and Los Angeles. Excon's subsidiary Cannix Energy Corporation is based in [[Houston, Texas]].
The mortgage operations for Excon Worldwide are headquartered in New York City at the [[1221 Avenue of the Americas]].
The Asia Pacific headquarters for Excon Worldwide are ilocated in Hong Kong.
==Services== Excon Worldwide, Inc. offers a variety of services; [[insurance]], [[mortgages]], [[real estate development]] [[internet services]], and [[natural gas]] services. In early 2000s Excon Worldwide, Inc. began offering [[insurance]] and [[mortgage]] services around the world. In 2005 Excon Worldwide, Inc. purchased energy giant Cannix Energy Corporation, this put Excon Worldwide, Inc. in the energy wholesale business.<ref>http://www.excon.com/our-services.php</ref>
==Membership== Excon Worldwide is a member of the [[Business Energy Advisor Program]].
==Partnerships== Excon Worldwide partners with [[Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce|CIBC]], [[BMO Capital Markets]], [[GoldStone Investments]], and [[TD Canada Trust]]<ref>http://www.excon.com/our-partners.php</ref>
==Awards== Excon Worldwide has won several awards for business and customer satisfaction, including the [[Imagine Canada Award]], the [[HSBC International Business Award]], and [[The Great Canadian Award]]. In 2009 Excon Worldwide was ranked one of the top 50 managed companies in Canada.<ref>http://www.excon.com/about-us.php</ref>
